Accessibility.html:
Overview

Momentum has keyboard operation built into all of its components, improving the experience for visually impaired users and other users who operate using the keyboard.

The Dialog component has been designed to meet the accessibility guidelines.

Interaction Guidance

Keyboard Interactions

All interactive elements must be operable using only a keyboard. Focus order should also be logical. Note: For checkboxes with info buttons

Started

Close Button (Non Modal only)

Secondary Button

Primary Button

When a dialog opens, focus moves to an element contained in the dialog. Generally, focus is initially set on the first focusable element. However, the most appropriate focus placement will depend on the nature and size of the content.
When a dialog closes, focus returns to the element that invoked the dialog.
It is strongly recommended that the tab sequence of all dialogs include a visible element with role button that closes the dialog, such as a close button or cancel button.

Screen Reader

When labels are implemented, the aria-label likely will require additional context to be announced by the screen reader. Decide what should be announced for the following: name, role and value. Accessibility labels should include both the label and role. Align the accessibility label (used for assistive technology devices like screen readers) with the visible label text (if any).

1

*Add aria-labelledby id on the dialog title. *Add aria-describeby

What is IDREF

IDREF is referring to the ID that is associated with the aria label. It is basically saying “Refer to ID” For the above example, we want the aria-labelledby to read out the modal title. So in HTML, you want to use the same ID for the modal title, and also include the same ID name on aria-labelledby in the parent div.

Spec.html:
Anatomy

*Optional, **X icon off by default on Modal Dialog

Tokens

*Tertiary Link is optional and should be only used when absolutely necesary **Refer to Button

Layout

Both Modals and Non Modal Dialog should have 20% padding from the top of the page (as shown below), and equal spacing on right & left for center alignment.

Full Screen

Responsive

For smaller screen sizes, Modals should have minimum of 12px padding on right & left side.
Modals will adjust to smaller screensize for responsiveness but will always keep the 12px padding.

Non Modal Dialog only have Medium (Default) Size.

Max height for both Default and Large component is 70% of the viewport. User a scrollbar for extra content. Footer stays fixed to the bottom as the content scrolls.

For smaller screen sizes, Modals should have minimum of 12px padding on right, left and bottom.

Modals will adjust to smaller screensize for responsiveness but will always keep the 12px padding.

Spacing

Dialog should have 16px padding all around and between most of the elements. Exceptions are 24px between the Body content and the Footer bottom links.

Guideline.html:
Overview

Dialogs are temporary overlay on top of the main content of a webpage or application. It typically includes a message, prompt, or form that requires the user to take action or provide information before they can continue using the app or website. Learn more here: https://www.nngroup.com/articles/modal-nonmodal-dialog/

Anatomy

*Optional, **X icon off by default on Modal Dialog

Use Cases

When to use Modal Dialog

Use a divider when:
Use a modal dialog when the system require an immediate response from the user. Request information that is preventing the system from continuing user’s process.
Use a modal dialog to notify the user of urgent information regarding their current process.
Use modal dialogs to report system errors or convey a consequence of a user’s action.
Use a modal dialog to confirm user decisions. Clearly describe the action being confirmed and explain any potential consequences that it may cause.

When NOT to use Modal Dialog

Do not use for complex decision making or wizard stepper process that requires information unavailable in the modal.
Do not use Modal Dialogs that interrupt processes that is already taking places, such as checkout.
Do not use Modal Dialogs for nonessential information that is not related to the current user flow.

When to use Non Modal Dialog

Use non-modal dialog to focus the user’s attention for a non-urgent notification.
Use for optional short task completion such as survey or review.
Use to gather optional input from the user such as email or other user information.
Use to display non-urgent, relevant information.

When to NOT use Non Modal Dialog

Do not use Non Modal Dialog for important information that required user’s immediate response.
Any process that is required in order for users to continue.
Do not user Non Modal Dialog to interrupt user’s process.

Types

Modals are not draggable or movable by mouse. Modals minimize with the app/browser.

Dos and Dont’s

Dos It is important to know when to use Modal Dialog vs Non-Modal Dialog. Below are some of the guidelines that will help you use the proper component for your use cases.

Use Case Example

Use dialogs for prompts that interrupt the user’s operation, such as critical information that requires a specific user response, task, decision, or acknowledgement.

Do not use Modal Dialogs for low to medium priority information. Instead, use a Non-Modal Dialog, Toaster or a banner which can be dismissed quickly or automatically.

Vertical separator vs. Stroke

The dialog title should be direct and clear. Title should explain what is required in the request, and provides clear actions. Users should be able to get an idea of the task just by reading the title.

Do not use dialog titles that pose an ambiguous question, unclear, and un-related.

Behavior

Dialogs are initiated by the user's actions and also generated by the system. Dialogs can be triggered by Call to Action by the user such as buttons, links, or icons. Pressing the Enter or Space key on a keyboard can activate a modal.

When Modal Dialog appears, it will generate a temporary overlay between the Dialog and the page to help the user can focus on the Dialog. To appear on the screen, dialogs will have a quick, but not instant, transition to appear and disappear.

As Modal Dialog requires user’s attention and action, the close icon will be off by default and clicking outside the modal on the screen overlay area will not close the Modal.

Content

A dialog’s purpose should be short, direct and easy to understand only by its title and call to actions.

Confirming actions are aligned to the ending side of the screen with dismissive actions on the leading side of the confirming action. For layouts using left-to-right languages, this means the confirming action is placed on the right, with the dismissing action to its left. This placement is reversed for right-to-left languages.

If a single action is provided, it must be an acknowledgement action
If two actions are provided, one must be a confirming action, and the other a dismissing action

Providing a third action, such as “Learn more,” is not recommended as it navigates the user away from the dialog, leaving the dialog task unfinished. It should only be used only when absolutely necessary.

Rather than adding a third action, an inline expansion can display more information. If more extensive information is needed, provide it prior to entering the dialog.

Title

Title should be brief, clear statement or a question. Headline should not show strong alarm, warning, apologetic wording or ambiguity. For success, warnings and errors, use Toaster.
Headlines should wrap, and not exceed more than two lines.

Body Content

Dialog should include only the content relevant to completing the current task shown. Although there are no work count limit, body content should still be direct and brief.

Overflow Content

Each dialog has a max width to maintain proper ratio of the dialog. When the dialog content is longer than the dialog container height, the body section will scroll vertically with the sticky header and sticky footer remaining fixed in its place. The scrollbar will appear on the right side of the dialog container, to indicate there are additional content outside the view. Dialog content should not scroll horizontally; designer should use a larger size modal.

Footer

For Modal Dialogs, use descriptive words such as Confirm, Add, Save etc. Avoid vague words like Done, OK, Close etc.

Usable Examples

Modal Dialog

Non Modal Dialog

Related Components

Toaster

If you need to show Call to Action interaction, use button
